Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Description_new:
Q3 2020
CEO Launch event: The CEO launch event was held on 28 July 2020 to much public interest and support from the South African business community. This CEO launch event milestone was held and attended by amongst others, the CEO’s of the country’s two most carbon intensive companies as per CDP – Eskom and Sasol. A sizeable number of CEOs from leading companies and key industry bodies have been recruited to champion the project. Leveraging the convening power of the NBI and BUSA (Business Unity South Africa). At the time of reporting 24 CEOs of listed companies agreed to be CEO champions, as well as the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and various industry bodies. On-boarding of more CEO’s is ongoing.
Q4 2020
CEO Champions Advisory Meeting: Pathways for the electricity sector to "Net Zero" by 2050. This meeting took place on 15th November 2020 and counted with the participation of 49 representatives from a diversity of companies, of which 20 were women. The meeting introduced the core project team, explained the scope of work for the project and its contribution to the South African climate targets and the just transition. The project explained the focus areas of the project in 2020 and provided an overview of the analysis and findings for the electricity sector, their modelling approach, the role of the just transition, and its links to broader social and economic agendas in the country. The feedback from the participants was positive overall.
Result_Title: CEO Champions Advisory Meetings
Description: A series of advisory meetings with the CEO champions aimed at identifying the pathways to "Net Zero" by 2050 in Petrochemical, Mining, and Electricity sectors. The first meeting will be the launch intended to inform a wide range of intended stakeholders about the project and its aims.

Project: Supporting the roll-out of smart grid technologies in Colombia
Description_new:
On December 17th, 2020, a final summary report which compiled the findings from the updated smart grid landscape and the Cost Benefit Analysis was delivered to UPME. The report quantifies the potential systemic benefit which could be triggered by the deployment of smart grids, including its contribution to reducing GHG emissions in a cost-effective manner. The report compiles all the recommendations regarding required technology and policy-related changes which would be necessary for unlocking these benefits through the deployment of smart grid technologies in the country. 
The importance of this report comes from the fact that it is the first study which quantifies the monetary benefits and avoided GHG emissions provided by the flexibility of smart grids in the Colombian electricity system. Through this project, savings in distribution infrastructure networks have been identified and quantified towards the year 2030 due to the flexibility provided by smart grids. These savings are in the order of USD 42 million annualized. In 2040 and 2050, savings in distribution continue to be relevant, but the savings in the need for generation facilities to decarbonize the system become much more relevant. 
UPME intends to make this report public on its new website, to be launched in December 2020, and use the key results as inputs to define the Colombian National Energy Plan 2050.
Result_Title: Summary report with recommendations for UPME for a cost-effective deployment of smart grids
Description:
Summary report to help UPME to update the Smart Grid roadmap focused on AMI, which is intertwined and the front runner across the smart technologies analysed (demand-side response schemes – DSR, vehicle to grid – V2G, and energy storage – ES).   
This report will include the recommended next actions on policy, market regulation, and technology to unlock the most cost-effective way to deploy smart grids.

Project: Implementing ESG disclosure and integration for a green and sustainable ‘two-way opening’ of the investment market in China
Description_new:
More than 1,000 stakeholders (investors, regulators, and policymakers) have attended capacity building sessions delivered by the project. In chronological order: 
(1) Trainings within the framework of the 2018 China SIF Week. 
An ESG disclosure consultation workshop was delivered in Hong Kong on December 4th, 2018, aimed to collect feedback on disclosure indicators and trends from international investors, as well as their views on A-share companies' ESG performance and future regulation. It was a close-door event delivered to 19 international investors (10 female). 
In addition, a PRI representative delivered a panel session as part of the Annual Conference on December 5th, 2018 to a total number of 320 attendees. No information on female participation was provided. The core of the presentation was how mandatory ESG information disclosure improves values of listed companies, and how to integrate ESG factors to realize robust investment in banking, insurance, and asset management sectors. Attendees included government officials, former chairman of National Social Security Fund, financial regulators (insurance and asset management), global and domestic investors, and service providers. 
(2) Direct engagement meeting with the research bureau of PBOC. June 3rd, 2019. 
The research bureau introduced their current work in green finance and the green bond market, while PRI introduced work on ESG in credit rating, ESG information disclosure, and discussed the work of the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS). A total of 7 people attended the meeting (5 female).
(3) Close-door workshop for NSSF.  June 3rd 2019
The project team hosted a closed-door workshop for NSSF on the integration of ESG factors in investment and risk management by pension funds, which included discussions on international, international best practices, and research on ESG disclosure in China. A total of 25 people attended this workshop (13 female)
(4) Three training sessions within the framework of the UNEP FI Regional Roundtable. June 5th, 2019
The training sessions provided insights into ESG credit risk and ratings, ESG disclosure in China (the ESG disclosure in China report was presented during the event) and ESG integration in the APAC region. A total of 473 people attended the training sessions. No information on female participation was provided.
(5) Trainings within the framework of the 2019 China SIF Week in Beijing. 
First, the project delivered a training event on 'Investor engagement and Climate Action 100+' to listed companies on December 2nd, 2019. The training focused on the Climate Action 100+ initiative, and mandatory ESG disclosure indicators, including GHG emissions. It was delivered to 330 attendees (around 170 were female) from listed companies from Shenzhen and Shanghai Stock Exchanges.
On the following day, the project delivered a session on 'ESG and Alpha in China'. The workshop was delivered to 70 attendees (35 were female) from Chinese asset management companies. The topics covered were ESG and Alpha research, and the presentation of case studies on how to integrate ESG into investment processes. Some of the companies represented were MSCI, China AMC, E-Fund, Harvest Fund, Hwabao WP Fund and BNP Paribas. 
Finally, a PRI representative delivered a panel session on ESG investing as part of the Annual Conference on December 3rd, 2019 to a total number of 330 attendees (around 170 were female).
Result_Title: Workshops on ESG disclosure and integration
Description: Consultation workshops. To be conducted with regulators, stock exchanges, domestic and international institutional investors and asset managers, companies, and key experts to enhance investor education on ESG disclosure and integration. The goal is to promote the effective implementation and market buy-in of the green and sustainable ‘two-way opening’ policy.

Project: Implementing ESG disclosure and integration for a green and sustainable ‘two-way opening’ of the investment market in China
Description_new:
The work around the policy recommendations for a 'two-way opening' of China's investment market focused on the importance of the design and implementation of consistent ESG disclosure rules for investors. 
Q2 2019
In June, 2019, PRI published their report 'ESG Data in China: Recommendations for Primary ESG Indicators', which showed that while there was broad alignment between international and Chinese corporate ESG data disclosure practices, the disclosures provided by Chinese companies are not standardised and not readily comparable across markets, industries and portfolios. The report commented that this lack of comparability limits investors’ ability to integrate ESG data into their investment decisions, and acts as a barrier to increased investment in green and sustainable assets. 
The report therefore recommended that Chinese financial regulators (CSRC) introduce a mandatory ESG disclosure framework, requiring all major companies to report on a series of standard ESG indicators and to supplement these quantitative metrics with related information on governance, strategy and risk management of ESG issues. Setting a mandatory ESG disclosure framework is expected to contribute positively to the ongoing ESG disclosure standardisation process on an international level. Moreover, making it mandatory for all Chinese listed companies to disclose information on a standardised set of ESG indicators, could give the Chinese market long-term motivation for enhanced and high-quality reporting on key ESG issues. 
The ultimate objective would be that this recommendations on ESG disclosure rules was integrated by the CSRC into their expected environmental disclosure framework, which was announced for 2020. Due to several delays unrelated to the regulator's work on ESG, this framework has not yet been announced.
Q2 2020
To support this key recommendation, the project translated the ‘EU asset manager disclosure regulation’ into Chinese, which encouraged the creation of disclosure requirements for sustainability risks among European investors, aiming to support the integration of ESG issues across asset classes and geographies. This regulation was also expected to encourage investors to understand and mitigate the potential adverse impacts of their investment on society and the environment. The project presented the translated investor disclosure rules, together with other examples of investor disclosure policies, to the CSRC in the second quarter of 2020. 
Finally, as part of the project’s cost extension, PRI completed an investor survey aimed to gather feedback from investors on the need and importance of a mandatory, standardised ESG disclosure framework in China. The implementation of this survey was a request from the CSRC. The survey was answered by 49 organisations (2 asset owners, 39 investment managers, and 8 service providers). Out of the 49 organisations, 25 were based in mainland China, 10 in Hong Kong, and 14 in other countries. Key findings from the survey indicated: 
1. Both domestic and international institutional investors have concerns about ESG information disclosure of China A-shares, especially the information related to ESG risks management. Those concerns mainly relate to i) lack of reliable ESG data (76%); ii) lack of comparable ESG data between Chinese companies (59%); and lack of comparable ESG data with international peers (53%).
2. Although an increasing number of companies publish sustainability reports, these do not systematically include quantified, standardised ESG information and do not provide meaningful data for investors.
3. 98% of respondents believe it is important to align with international frameworks and metrics. 
4. International investors expressed in the survey that if the A-shares improve ESG information disclosure, they will have more interest in investing in China, which indicates that better ESG information disclosure can promote the ‘two-way opening’ of the China’s capital market. 
The survey results were presented at a webinar on June 2020, with the participation of CIFCM. The full results were published in a dedicated research briefing in July 2020.
Result_Title: Policy recommendations for a green and sustainable ‘two-way opening’ of China’s investment market
Description: Policy recommendations for a green and sustainable ‘two-way opening’ of China’s investment market.

Project: Sustaining the Growth of China’s Green Bond Market and Facilitating Inter-Country Green Capital Flows
Description_new:
The project undertakes an ongoing dissemination of products on China's Green Bond market.
1) China Green Bond Market Annual Report 2018; 
2) Market quarterly newsletters;
3) Between two and three blog posts per month. 
4) An initial discussion paper on comparison of Chinese and EU green definitions in November 2019. 
Q3 2020
In the third quarter of 2020, the project published a blog post with recommendations for the sustained and high-quality development of China's green bond market. 
The project also made available to China-based audience more than 40 webinars hosted by CBI on international green finance standards and green bond market development. 
Communication products are vital for the project to publicize the important development in the global/Chinese green finance and green bond field - it is one of the few windows for the world to keep track of China's development in green finance/bonds and to allow Chinese stakeholders keep abreast of international development in the green bond space.

Description: Publishing materials. Market quarterly newsletter, annual report, and market blogs in both Chinese and English.

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
Significant advances have been made on the identification and development of a portfolio of sustainable transport projects in the four participating cities. The list of selected projects is the following: 
Medellin
- Metro de la 80: 13-kilometre-long light rail project with 17 stations. 
- Cycling infrastructure densification project: 40 kilometres of cycling lanes laid-out throughout the city.
Cali
- Tren de Cercanías: 70-kilometre regional train connecting the municipality of Cali with neighbouring municipalities of Palmira, Yumbo and Jamundí.
- Sustainable mobility project: construction of 110 kilometres of cycling lanes and 161 new bicycle parking modules. 
Pereira
- Mega Cable: new cable car project for the city of Pereira. Currently in structuring phase. 
- Electric buses: replacement of 40 articulated buses and 116 small buses, from combustion to electric technologies. 
Monteria
- Businú phase 2: river transportation system along the Sinú river. 
- Bicired: construction of 80 kilometres of cycling lanes.
In addition to the identification of the sustainable mobility projects in each city, the project has already conducted a technical evaluation for each one of them. The technical evaluations include calculations of the projects’ potential for GHG emissions reductions, co-benefits expected, potential gender impact, estimation of implementation costs, economic appraisal, risk assessments, and identification of key barriers. 
Pending tasks include the drafting of final the final projects’ reports and fact sheets.
Result_Title: Set of potential projects to be implemented to decarbonize the transport sector
Indicator: Output 2.3. 'Project application/ tools developed to access funds'
Description: Identify a set of potential projects which could be implemented in Medellin, Cali, Pereira and Monteria to decarbonize the transport sector. Utilise robust and coherent information in order to present the portfolio to climate finance funds: calculate the potential reduction of GHG emissions that would be generated if the projects are implemented, estimate costs of projects’ implementation, estimate projects’ co-benefits, and identify barriers.

A great example of this interest is that CBI worked with the residential construction experts present in the round table for the assessment of the EcoCasa as proxy in the CBI criteria. The approval of the certification means that now Mexico has a local code for residential low carbon buildings recognized by an international standard, which allows to measure and monitor GHG emission reductions in Mexico.

Project: Building a sustainable and scalable low carbon future in Mexico<U+200B>
Description_new:
On September 17th, 2020, the project began the delivery of a pilot open-sourced, Diploma on Green Finance, aimed to improve the knowledge of sustainable finance among relevant actors in the country. The course was delivered between September 17th and October 19th, with an overall duration of 28 hours. 
Out of the 54 applications received by the course, 35 people were accepted (22 female). The training participants were selected for their position at relevant institutions or organizations who were expected to be able to apply their gained knowledge in the short/medium term. Participants to the course belonged to the following institutions: Amdee, Banco Nacional de Comercio Exterior, Banobras, Banorte, The Bank of Mexico, BBVA, BIVA, Carbon Trust, Centro Interdisciplinario de Estudios e Investigaciones sobre Medio Ambiente y Desarrollo (CIIEMAD) -IPN, CKD Infraestructura México, CNBV, Conacyt, Consejo Nacional de Sostenibilidad y Regeneración UMA, Despachos Jurídicos, Ethos Laboratorio Jurídico (Think tank), ITAM, en proceso en Banxico, Procura Regulatory Consulting, Sacromonte Ganuc de México SC, Seguros Monterrey New York Life, SENER, SHCP, UK PACT.
The topics covered by the training were: 
1) Theoretical framework of climate change and economic impacts, major international agreements on SDGs and voluntary initiatives promoted by the international financial community, and fundamentals on sustainable finance. 
2) Conceptual framework of risk analysis, integration of ESG criteria in decision making, methodologies and agreements on ESG risk assessment, and performance of investments incorporating ESG criteria. 
3) Case studies on the incorporation of ESG risk assessments on investments. 
4) Green market trends and key actors, concepts of labelling and certification, and the role of investors, multilateral banks, and regulators within this new market. 
5) Transition and environmental risks, actions to integrate risks analysis into routine decision making, and analysis of available tools in the market. 
The project expects to collect relevant feedback for this pilot course and set it as an example as a comprehensive training on green finance, with the ultimate objective of being integrated into ITAM’s curriculum and thus reach a wider audience interested in the topic.
Result_Title: Diploma in Green Finance
Description: Delivery of a pilot open-sourced, course curriculum on green finance to improve the knowledge of green finance to relevant actors in the country.

Project: Building a sustainable and scalable low carbon future in Mexico<U+200B>

CNBV is currently reviewing the guidelines developed by the project, which are likely to be published throughout the course of the year.

Project: Scaling up Green Finance and establishing building blocks for scalable and low carbon investment in Colombia
Description_new:
Q2 2020
A first draft on sector criteria for a Colombian green taxonomy was developed together with partners and discussed with the IFC. This first draft was developed following a series of meetings with key government institutions such as Superintendencia Financiera, Ministry of Hacienda, and DNP.  Priority sectors for which these criteria were developed are Energy, Transport and Waste Management, Construction, and Agriculture, Forestry, and Land Use (AFOLU). 
Moreover, the project worked with the IFC to identify, within the main sectors, the fast tracks or 'easy wins' to possibly constitute the first set of taxonomy activities in Colombia. It was also agreed that for adaptation, the project would review the national adaptation plans and then cross-check them with the international taxonomies. The project also brought key technical experts into the discussions, as well as representatives from DANE and MADS.
Q4 2020
CBI stated that it will continue to support the taxonomy development out of the project to provide the inputs needed to finalize it.
Result_Title: Green guidelines outlining local definitions for what qualifies as ‘green’
Description: Based on the sector analysis, development of green guidelines outlining local definitions for what qualifies as ‘green’ and detailed sector-specific criteria for priority sectors (specifically transport). These will be aligned with global standards and best practices.

Project: Scaling up Green Finance and establishing building blocks for scalable and low carbon investment in Colombia
Description_new: The support provided by CBI to the development of a green taxonomy (green guidelines) was very well received by the beneficiaries. Their acceptance of this process is demonstrated by their agreement on continuing with the development of the first Colombian taxonomy draft. The institutions which will now be coordinating the work will primarily be the Superintendencia Financiera and the Ministry of Finance, together with the DANE, DNP and MinAmbiente. The work on the taxonomy is currently evolving around seven main sectors: energy, buildings, water, waste management, ICT, transport, and industry. CBI is a co-leader of some of them.
Result_Title: Adoption of the sector-adapted green definitions
Indicator: Int. Out 2. 'Adoption of recommendation for policy/legislation'
Description: Key stakeholders show interest/agreement on the development and approval of  green guidelines outlining local definitions for what qualifies as ‘green’ and detailed sector-specific criteria for priority sectors.

Project: Climate Transition Pathways
Description_new: This meeting took place on 24th February 2021 and counted with the participation of 34 representatives from a diversity of companies, of which 13 were women. The purpose of the meeting was to share key findings from modelling exercises in the electricity sector and petrochemicals sectors and the initial review for just transition for coal value was completed. The agenda also covered achieving a net zero power mix, decarbonizing South Africa’s petrochemicals sector and the role of gas in energy transition in South Africa. The meeting ended with a discussion of the next steps which would be work in agriculture, forestry and other land use and transport sector.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support

The first session, attended by 22 people, covered an overview of Cape Town's EV work and the second session, attended by 21 people, dived into the details of Cape Town's EV energy demand forecast. Detailed inputs were given by the City of Cape Town EV team and robust discussion took place to enable the desired learning exchange.
Result_Title: First of two EV learning exchange workshops between City of Cape Town and City of Joburg
Description: An online learning exchange (half-day to full day, depending on availability & agenda). Aims to build Johannesburg staff capacity on policy / project levers / methods of EV implementation / support through knowledge-sharing on learnings from EV work undertaken by Cape Town, specifically (but not limited to) the EV Tariff Briefing document, their solar-powered EV charging stations, EV buses and EV fleet pilot.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new: The meeting had the participation of representatives from City of Johannesburg, City Power and SEA. Lebo Molefe and Thabo Mahlatsi (Directors in the Environment & Infrastructure Services Department) formally adopted the project into their Department. The steering committee, composed by representatives of City of Johannesburg, City Power and SEA, was agreed on and participants were excited to see the project get underway.
Result_Title: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Steering Committee established
Description: Committed participation from senior officials in the departments of climate change, energy (City Power), finance, transport and planning. The steering committee will provide guidance on alignment with city goals, on vertical alignment, and champion acceleration of EV uptake in the city.

Project: Capacity Building for Chinese Financial Institutions on Climate Transition Risk Methodologies
Description_new:
The project successfully hosted a 90-minutes webinar on 3rd June 2020 to introduce climate transition risks assessment methodology and tools to Chinese financial institutions. Besides Carbon Trust experts, the project also invited Dr. SUN Tianyin, a scholar in Tsinghua University, to attend the webinar and introduced the first locally designed climate transition risks assessment tool that was designed by his team. Over 110 participants dialled in to the webinar, including representatives from leading commercial banks, asset management companies, as well as central and policy banks, who explicitly expressed interest but requested to keep a low profile. The event lasted half a day, and no information on the gender of the attendees was provided. 
In addition to the webinar, the project has also been holding short trainings (1 hour each) with representatives of key financial institutions in order to conduct project interviews in a more efficient way. The stakeholders with whom formal conversations were established are: 
ICBC, Mrs. YIN Hong; CIB, Mrs. CHEN Quan; Bank of Jiangsu, Mr. WANG Lei; China Agriculture Development Bank (CADB), Mr. CHEN Yulin, Mr. Li Ang,  and Mrs. HUA Yi; UNPRI China office, Mrs. LUO Nan, Mrs. AI Wen, Dr. SUN Tianyin (the leading expert on climate transition risks in Tsinghua University), and Mrs. ZHOU Rong (a leading environment expert in engaging with commercial banks, a current consultant at IFC); China Development Bank, Mr. WANG Weihua; Industrial Bank Research Group, Ms. QIAN Lihua; and Maanshan Rural Commercial Bank, Ms. WANG Yan. Around 64% are females. 
Their feedbacks and questions were all fed into the webinar and improved the effectiveness of the large capacity building session too.
Result_Title: Training of Chinese financial institutions
Description: Based on the content produced for the chapter on climate transition risk of the NGFS handbook, a workshop for Chinese financial institutions will be run. This will include presentations and training sessions during GIP organized meetings, or other forums, and targeted meetings with key stakeholders.

Project: Capacity Building for Chinese Financial Institutions on Climate Transition Risk Methodologies
Description_new:
In the first quarter of 2020, the project concluded the draft of the chapter on climate transition risk assessment tools and methodologies and submitted it to the Central Banks and Supervisors’ Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) team, to be incorporated into the handbook titled 'Overview of Environmental Risk Analysis by Financial Institutions'. 
The official title of the chapter was 'Case Studies of Environmental Risk Analysis Methodologies. 
The chapter discusses the key characteristics of existing approaches to assess transition risks for financial institutions and develops a criteria framework to help financial institutions select the most suitable methodologies. The criteria are separated into three broad groups: i) general applicability, based on the types of transition risks covered, scenarios and outputs; ii) coverage considerations, based on geographies, asset classes, sectors, and levels of analysis; and iii) practicality and implementation, based on data requirements, integration challenges, costs and development stage of the methodologies. The chapter also identifies overarching methodological limitations to inform end-users, supervisors, and methodology developers.
Carbon Trust's impartial position on the topic provides a unique angle to provide an overview of all the tools and further share with the audience on what are the aspects to be considered while selecting a transition risks assessment tool. 
The handbook was released on September 10th, 2020.
Result_Title: Chapter on climate transition risk assessment methodologies and tools in NGFS handbook
Description:
Contribution to the NGFS handbook by writing the chapter on climate transition risk
assessment tools and methodologies and providing ongoing technical support on the topic ahead of the formal release of the handbook in April 2020.

Project: Capacity Building for Chinese Financial Institutions on Climate Transition Risk Methodologies
Description_new:
In the third quarter of 2020, the project finished a bilingual report on climate transition risk assessments titled 'How to Anticipate a Green Swan Event. Preparing Chinese Financial Markets for Climate Transition risk'. 
The report starts by presenting the concept of climate-related risks and then presents a series of tools and methodologies for climate transition risks assessments. The report also presents a detailed analysis of the current status and key challenges faced by China on the topic and discusses potential ways forward for regulators and financial institutions. 
The report was released and presented during the Green Investment Principles (GIP) webinar on September 10th. The webinar was hosted by the GIP Secretariat with Dr Ma Jun delivering opening remarks. Carbon Trust expert Ben Peel presented the report findings. 
Participants to the event included key GIP signatories, and the pilot organizations of the UK-China TCFD pilot. A total of 51 people attended the event.
Result_Title: Report on climate transition risk assessment methodologies and tools in English and Chinese
Description: A standalone report on climate transition risk assessment methodologies and tools will be produced. The report will be in both English and Chinese for use in capacity building and broader awareness-raising purposes for stakeholders in China. The report will be publicly released at an appropriate venue (for example during a GIP organized workshop)

Project: Capacity Building for Chinese Financial Institutions on Climate Transition Risk Methodologies
Description_new:
Some evidence of initial adoption of the skills and knowledge acquired by key stakeholders was observed in the third quarter of 2020: 
ICBC (interviewee was Mrs. YIN Hong) are considering conducting a stress-testing exercise, which is an important risk management tool which is used to assess the resilience of banks and financial systems in general to potential shocks. 
CIB (interviewee was Mrs. CHEN Quan) are considering undertaking climate risk/TCFD pilot work in either one sector of activity, or at one regional branch. 
Industrial Bank Research Group (interviewee was Mr. CHEN Yulin) are considering including climate risk assessment to their capacity building function with SME banks in China.
Result_Title: Adoption of skills and knowledge on climate transition risk
Indicator: Int. Out 1 'Enhanced action because of training'
Description: Knowledge and skills acquired through training and knowledge products are adopted.

Project: Scaling up Green Finance and establishing building blocks for scalable and low carbon investment in Colombia
Description_new:
To provide further reach of the recommendations on establishing a Green Debt Fund and the Warehousing Finance instrument, the project held a dissemination event on November 5th, 2020. Some of the institutions who were present at the event were members of the SISCLIMA, multilateral banks, and other financial institutions. 
The event was co-delivered with the Colombian Stock Exchange (BVC), which portrays the interest of the institution on the promotion of these financial instruments.
After the event, several institutions further reached out to have more information on what would be necessary to establish it. The Ministry of Finance and the Colombian Stock Exchange continue being interested in utilizing and promoting the instrument.
Result_Title: Agreement on the establishment of a Green Debt Fund
Indicator: Int. Out 3. 'Adoption of recommendation for other action'
Description: Green Fund concept note is of  widespread use across Colombia and concepts such as warehousing are well understood across the market.

Project: Creating Enabling Conditions for Just Transition in México
Description_new:
On April 19th, 2021, the project published two reports which assessed some of the environmental, economic, and social implications of different scenarios of coal power generation in Mexico. 
The first report, titled ‘From coal to renewables: an economic analysis for an electric transition in Mexico’, proposed a coal phase-out scenario for 2030 and estimated the economic impacts that such transition would have on GDP and jobs creation. The report also proposed five alternative strategies for economic diversification in the ‘Coal Region’, detailing potential compensation policies for specific population.  
The second report, ‘Analysis of perceptions on jobs’ quality in the coal region’, conducted a qualitative analysis to better understand experts and communities’ perceptions on jobs related to the coal industry, and how their conditions compare to jobs in other sectors.  
Both reports were published at WWF and Coahuila’s Autonomous University’s websites.
Result_Title: Assessment of three scenarios of coal power generation
Description: An assessment of some environmental, economic and social implications, based on three scenarios of coal power generation at 2030: BAU, significant reduction, and complete elimination, in line with NDCs emissions reduction targets and compliance with Powering Past Coal Alliance.

Project: Mobilization of private investment to implement energy efficiency measures in the industrial sector in Colombia
Description_new: During the first quarter of 2020, the project delivered a report which outlines identified barriers, solutions implemented, lessons learned, and key recommendations for the design and implementation of successful industrial energy efficiency projects in five relevant countries, including the UK.  Some key topics of discussion: energy consultant certifications and financial mechanisms, and long-term sustainability of EE projects. The report is contextualised and adapted to the local Colombian industrial context.
Result_Title: Report on lessons learned on the design and implementation of industrial energy efficiency projects
Description: Generate a report which identifies barriers, solutions implemented to overcome those barriers, and lessons learned from the design and implementation of successful industrial EE projects of five relevant countries including the UK, adapted to the local Colombian industrial context.

Project: Capacity building for green investment and the Green Investment Principles(GIP)
Description_new: Delivered a baseline assessment report for green finance in Central Asia to evaluate the development progress and regional best practices in Mongolia, Kazakhstan and Pakistan. This report also provides recommendations aiming at enhancing green finance capacity-building.
Result_Title: Green Finance Research Report for Central Asia
Description: Baseline report to discover the current state of green finance in Central Asia and help project’s stakeholders better understand the regional opportunities for green investment and financing. It will also combine the expertise of GIP members and pre-existing tools (e.g. green project database) with original analysis to develop a financing gap analysis and roadmap for Central Asia.
Implementor: Beijing Institute of Finance and Sustainability

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description_new:
CDP has responded to policy consultations and arranged three meetings in Q1 with staff of CSRC, MEE and SEE:
1.	CDP submitted a response to the public consultation on the Guidelines for Investor Relations Management of Listed Companies of China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) on March 5th, 2021, and organised a discussion with the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) to collect further suggestions.
2.	CDP met an analyst of the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) on 18 March 2021 to learn updated status of upcoming disclosure regulations. The analyst is in charge of drafting disclosure regulations which is expected to be released in 2021/2022. Following the meeting, CDP provided its Climate Change indicators and Prototype climate-related financial disclosure standard to support CSRC’s research.
3.	CDP had a catch up meeting with the Chinese Academy of Environmental Planning (CAPE), an Institute of the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE) on 23 March  2021. Following this meeting, CDP provided its Climate Change indicators to support CAPE’s research on law-based environmental information disclosure. CAPE will be influential in recommending/advising the types of indicators that will be adopted by CSRC new regulatory framework.

Description: Quarterly updates/meetings with policy makers from the MEE and the CSRC . The purpose of the meetings is to check in with policy makers to provide progress of policy launch and update them on trends on CDP's disclosure progress in China. The MEE, with CSRC, is co-leading policy development on corporate mandatory environmental disclosure, but its team is relatively new to disclosure issues. These regular engagements will therefore also support enhanced mutual understanding of environmental data demands/needs from the investor perspective.

Project: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration
Description_new: Q1 newsletter has been completed and sent to 51 stakeholders including contacts in CSRC, MEE, CBIRC, NGOs, Companies and Financial institutions. The content of the newsletter includes recent insights of environmental disclosure, and briefly introduces the objectives, approaches and plan of CDP’s 2021 UK PACT Project.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new: The meeting had representatives from City of Johannesburg, City Power, Department of Transport, GIZ, SANEDI, SEA and UNIDO. The objectives of the meeting were: to provide an overview of the Johannesburg EV Readiness Support Programme and the local context in relation to EV development, including existing policies and programmes at the national and local level and garner input on what an EV future would look like, including vision elements, the City's role and stakeholders involved. National Department of Transport presented their Green Transport Strategy and SANEDI presented their Cleaner Mobility Programme. Both initiatives align exceptionally with the CoJ EV Readiness Project and the buy-in of national stakeholders was guaranteed. Stakeholders requested to be kept abreast with project progress.

Description: Committed participation from key relevant national stakeholders to ensure that the project builds on existing work/knowledge, engenders buy-in, is in line with national policy/regulations (e.g. national EV Framework currently being developed), and links into any other potential knowledge dissemination networks. This will result in broad buy-in and a robust policy briefing document that can form the basis of work in other cities wishing to undertake similar work.

Project: China Skill Share: Training to enhance understanding of domestic and global green finance development and Shenzhen's newly-issued Green Finance Regulation
Description_new:
On 25th and 26th March 2021, Shenzhen held green finance training for financial institutes and regulators registered in the Shenzhen economic zone. This was a one and half day event supported by Shenzhen Local Financial and Supervisory Management Bureau and the People’s Bank of China Shenzhen Centre Branch. The training was to help their financial institutions to better understand the newly launched "Shenzhen Special Economic Zone Green Finance Regulations" and the necessary implementation measures. The aim of the event was to help enhance awareness and knowledge, and learn from international best practice. As such, our experts (Joss Blamire and Rachel Brisley) each developed and pre-recorded a 45-minute presentation on one of the key themes at the event (both presented on 25th March). 

Rachel presented on climate risk assessment and stress testing for the financial service sector in Shenzhen. She considered Shenzhen’s changing climate, impacts for financial institutions and other businesses, global trends and best practices on stress testing and climate risk assessment methodology. Joss presented on TCFD, a framework to help companies report on exposure to climate-related risks and opportunities. He provided a high level introduction to TCFD, best practice for disclosures to make in a report, and a roadmap to work towards producing a report. He explained what the TCFD recommendations are and why they are adopted worldwide. Both experts used relevant case studies to help illustrate their content.

The event was supported by Shenzhen Local Financial and Supervisory Management Bureau and People’s Bank of China Shenzhen Centre Branch. 97 financial institutions (with over 100 audience members) attended the training event, as well as Shenzhen financial regulators. We received feedback forms from 28 attendees (which have been attached/manually uploaded). This low number was likely due to the language challenge (the feedback forms were only in English). Other attendees may not have wanted to complete the forms.
Result_Title: Green finance development and regulatory training sessions (TCFD) with senior officials from Shenzhen government and financial institutions
Description:
A 2-day training programme with senior officials from the Shenzhen government and financial institutions to develop an enhanced understanding of domestic and global green finance development, especially on information disclosure, climate risk assessment and green investment. The goal is to enhance green finance awareness and knowledge in relation to Shenzhen’s newly issued Green Finance Regulation and give them an opportunity to learn from international best practice.
Presentation slides will be shared with the Shenzhen Financial Services Office (Shenzhen FSO).

Project: Green Finance for the development of Smart Cities in Mexico II, working to accelerate the implementation of low carbon local projects and sustainable development
Description_new: Municipalities Projects Matrix Database: Longlist of projects from beneficiary cities  in the sectors of renewable energies, waste or water management, sustainable mobility or land use and with enough information available  to be subject to an evaluation to determine their degree of eligibility to receive technical assitance towards bankability
Result_Title: Integration of a list of municipal low carbon projects that meet aminimum criteria to be subject to a feasibility evaluation.
Description: Beneficiary cities will provide sets of information of their low carbon  projects and initiatives for us to integrate a complete long list of initiatives which will  be the input for a subsequent evaluation. The planned deliverables are: 1. An excel with an analysis of the complete list of projects provided by the cities

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description_new:
The Marketing Working Group (MWG) of Perijá was established during the first visit to the destination on the 10th of March 2021, with high engagement and commitment. This group was trained with the material of the first marketing workshop. The group committed to work together throughout the year to structure the marketing scheme of the destination. The group involves people from the 3 touristic agencies, that are committed to work together. There are young people in the groups who are skilled in social media and content development. They know they need to work more in the administrative aspects of marketing. The MWG is conformed by 9 people, where 22% are women (2 women). 

In Quinchas, the Marketing Working Group was established on the 19th of March 2021. However, since the communities are so far from each other, and many people didn't know each other, there is a need to work harder to support them in their marketing skills, specially because they are in remote areas and not connected to wifi. There is an option have some young people in Otanche supporting in this endeavor. The PDP is committed to working with the communities to make sure they agree on working together to market Las Quinchas as a whole destination. The MWG is conformed by 19 people where 58% are women (11 women).
Result_Title: Establish Market Working Group (MWG) in Quinchas and Perijá
Description: Establishment of two (2) Marketing Working Group (MWG), one in Quinchas and one in Perijá. This refers to the group of people that will receive all the trainings, to then lead and implement the marketing activities, strategies and tools. These groups are expected to be of 5-8 people per region.

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description_new:
1). Yearly Plan agreed with communities (Q1): 

First sessions to strengthen the tourism networks were held during the first visits to Perijá and Quinchas between the 8th and 19th of March 2021. In Perijá, there were two (2) formal half day sessions in La Victoria and La Jagua, plus two (2) visits to La Victoria and Estados Unidos, to speak to people interested in the culinary and homestays component.  In Quinchas, one day was spent in each community (17th march in Nazareth Altasor and 18th march in Betania); since they are so geographically apart, sessions were held separately with each community. 

During these sessions, there was a kick-off meeting where communities remembered where they left off last year, and presented and agreed on the yearly plan, defining specific dates for the first second trimester of the year. During these sessions, the different groups of people were formed, according to their interest in a specific component of the touristic chain (biodiversity guidance, culinary, homestays, marketing and admin). 

The communities in both regions are excited and highly engaged with the continuation of the project, and agreed with keeping the community-agreements on the benefit-sharing philosophy of the project. The initial touristic routes were also discussed and reorganized, and the communities committed to testing them before the next activity occurred. The outcome to agree the yearly plan was achieved in both regions.

The attendance to each region and session was:

Perijá: 
ºMarch 9 (La Victoria): 13 people attended (30% women).
ºMarch 9 (sesion 1 afternoon in la Jagua): 15 people attended (47% women).
ºMarch 10 (morning session): 11 people attended (45% women).

Quinchas:
ºMarch 17th (Nazareth-Altazor communities): 21 people attended (47% women).
ºMarch 18th (Betania Quinchas): 15 people attended (53% women).
Result_Title: Participative sessions to strengthen the network to develop tourism in Quinchas and Perijá
Description:
Two (2) Yearly Plan agreed with communities at the beginning of the project,  and two (2) final debriefing sessions to strengthen the tourism network within Quinchas and Perijá.

1). Yearly Plan agreed with communities (2021 Q1):

Session with communities, one per region, to define workplan and schedule of implementation of the project activities, to guarantee coordination and functional role assigning amongst all the beneficiaries and consortium partners. 

2). Final debriefing session with communities on the overall project and ways forward (2022 Q1):

Final debriefing sessions, one per region, where communities will learn from the one year experience with the project.  The debriefing session will be with project partners to acknowledge the learnings and to ensure that their future tourism endeavours involve all the learnings, recommendations and feedbacks to move forward. 
It will include a survey for the communities to evaluate the one-year project and to assess the usefulness of the overall process and learnings.

Project: Supporting livelihoods through Ecotourism Routes for Forest and Peace.
Description_new:
1). MARKETING AND ADMIN WORKSHOP # 1: During the first entry to each territory, an introductory workshop to destination marketing and administration for community ecotourism was delivered. It was highly practical and interactive, with various sub groups activities. The first part of the workshop talked about the importance of understanding community marketing, as opposed to individual marketing, and highlighted the benefits the community as a whole received from ecotourism, even if sometimes, not every one would receive monetary income. The second part of the workshop spoke about the principles of marketing, and how these reflected in the user journey when dreaming, booking, experiencing, and sharing a touristic destination. Finally, all the activities that derive from the marketing and admin roles were discussed and listed, and each person selected 3 roles or tasks he/she thought would have some experience and knowledge to support the overall marketing task. This allowed us to see where there was more knowledge, and the challenges to support in some aspects like the administrative roles, that will need to be supported during the year.

The attendees to these workshops were the people selected in the Marketing Working Group. In Perijá, 9 people attended (2 of them women). In Quinchas,  19 people (11 of them women).
Result_Title: Community workshops to enhance the capacity of the communities in Quinchas and Perijá to use marketing tools with allocated responsibilities
Description:
Training composed of 7 workshops per region to enhance capacities to use marketing tools delivered to the Marketing Working Group (MWG) established with the communities of Quinchas and Perijá. MWG will be composed around 5-8 people per region. Topics of the workshops include:

Marketing Workshop 1 to be delivered in Quinchas. Topics include:
a) Collaborative working; 
b) Introduction to  marketing.  
Training form: face-to-face. 
Duration: one day per territory

Marketing Workshop 2 about Marketing Planning Sessions to be delivered in Quinchas. Topics include:  
a) Target markets; 
b) Marketing Plan; 
c) Digital Content Plan and Content Creation. 
Training form: face-to-face. 
Duration of workshop: 2 days 

Marketing Workshop 3: Website Sessions
a) Website, Wordpress, Blogs. 
Training form: virtual. 
Duration of workshop: one day per territory.

Marketing Workshop 4 about Social Media Marketing to be delivered in Quinchas. Topics include:
a) How to set goals, monitor, measure, improve
b) Understand the booking process: Dreaming, Planning, Booking, Experiencing
c) Content and messaging: focusing on experiences that inspire customers
Training form: face-to-face. 
Duration of workshop: 1 day 

Marketing Workshop 5 about Sales training to be delivered in Quinchas. Topics include:
a) General Sales Training & preparing a pitch for tour operators; 
b) Developing and Practicing Sales Techniques.  
Training form: face-to-face. 
Duration of workshop: 1 day per territory

Marketing Workshop 6 about Social Media + OTAs to be delivered in Quinchas. Topics include:
a) Influencer Social Media Tips
b) Working with Online Travel Agents: what are OTAs and which is best for these communities (Airbnb, Viator, Travelingspoon, etc). Legal issues, pricing, operational issues, management of bookings.  
Number of people trained: 5-8 per territory. 
Training form: face-to-face. 
Duration of workshop: 1 day per territory

Marketing Workshop 7 to Finalise Planning for 2021-22 in Quinchas. Topics include:
a) Finalise Marketing Plan; 
b) Finalise Content Plan. 
Feedback and follow up with both communities.  
Number of people trained: 5-8 per territory.  
Training form: face-to-face 
Duration of workshop: 1 day per territory.

Project: Expanding the Colombian Climate Asset Disclosure Initiative (CCADI)
Description_new:
1). First of three follow-up reports on engagement with prioritised investors. CCADI will continue providing support to five (5) investors identified in 2020, and intends to agree with at least two (2) more investors to be part of the process of implementing recommendations this year. The 5 investors already involved are:

- Previsora S.A. Insurance Company
- Positiva Insurance Company S.A.
- Porvenir fondo de pensiones y cesantías S.A.
- La Equidad Seguros S.A.
- Skandia S.A.

In order to define the additional 2 investors, 18 more investors were contacted using the database of the responses from 2019. As of the end of 2021-Q1, no response had been obtained. 

Regarding the support process with the investors already engaged, initial meetings were agreed to be held in April, except for Positiva which was held on 24 March 2021, and Porvenir which is to be defined. 

The meeting with Positiva resulted in an improvement of the CCADI tool to better show improvements since 2019 up until now, which in Positiva's case is in overall a 16% improvement. In addition, Positiva confirmed it's interest to continue engaged, and would like to focus it's efforts in identifying climate change risks and to raise awareness among senior management and
members of the Board of Directors on the risks of climate change.
Result_Title: Provide and follow-up on personalised recommendations to the investors that answer the questionnaire to enhance investment decision-making and strategic actions in line with climate objectives
Description:
With the purpose of scaling up the impact built by CCADI’s implementation in 2019 and 2020, the Initiative will continue to support the follow-up on personalised recommendations to pension funds and insurance companies. This process will be completed by using a follow-up tool developed by the project. As a result, CCADI will report on the current status of the recommendations, whether they have been implemented by institutional investors, or not, and the reasons behind. 
Progress reports will be presented in 2021-Q1, 2021-Q2 and 2021-Q3.

All final personalised recommendations to each investor that answers the questionnaire will be presented in 2022 Q1. 

It is expected that asset owners are taken to a position to act on the recommendations in an upward spiral, catalysed by the ranking that can be followed up by the relevant stakeholders in Colombia.

Project: Expanding the Colombian Climate Asset Disclosure Initiative (CCADI)
Description_new:
The first Tools Webinar, out of three, was held on the 18 March 2021. The theme of the event was: The Financial Implications of Climate Change. Perspectives and Tools for Addressing Climate Change. 

In the webinar, a total of 20 companies (35 people), corresponding to 7 entities from the financial sector, including banks, pension funds, insurance companies, the central bank, were connected in the specific space to present the climate risk tool.
Result_Title: Series of skill enhancements workshops for capacity building and peer to peer knowledge sharing between public and private asset owners in Colombia and the UK
Description:
Due to the complex nature of climate change and the lack of installed capacity needed to manage risks and opportunities, asset owners require additional training to kick-start and scale up actions towards emissions reduction. For this, the main training activities will take place:
 
1). Thematic Workshops:
 
Number of workshops: Two Workshops (2021-Q2 and 2021-Q3)
Type: Virtual conference, through platforms such as Teams or WebEx. They will be recorded and available at CDP Education platform to any additional interested public. 
Target: Directed to private funds, banks, pension funds, insurance sector companies and real sector companies. It is expected that at least one participant from 10 organisations attend.
Content: Climate change risks and opportunities (in April 2021) and Reporting practices under TCFD (in June 2021).
In general, we are hoping to enroll company representatives that will attend all the modules. However, missing a specific session will not affect the attendees overall performance.
Duration: 2 hours each workshop

2). One (1) peer-to-peer mission to UK:

3 day meeting with UK peers for knowledge sharing and skills enhancement to be delivered on 2022-Q1.

Directed to public and private asset owners and asset managers, regulators and/or public officials

It is expected that at least one participant from 7 different organizations attend.
If COVID crisis does not allow travel the peer to peer mission will be held virtually.

3). Strategic Meeting with UK organisations:

Number: One meeting to be delivered on 2022-Q1.
Type: Bilateral meeting to take place in the same UK peer mission.
Target: Strategy discussion of CCADI staff  and UK organizations with experience in similar projects (ShareAction and ClientEarth)
Duration: 2 hours 

4). Tools Workshops:

Number: Three (3) Workshops to be delivered on 2021-Q1, 2021-Q2, and 2021-Q3.
Type: Virtual conference, through platforms such as Teams or WebEx. The workshops will be on the use of tools or the use of CDP´s and CCADI´s tools  (March, May and July ).
Target: Directed to institutional investors (pension funds and insurance companies). It is expected that at least one participants from 5 organisations attend.
Duration: 2 hours each workshop

Project: Steering the Colombian Road Freight Sector Towards a Zero Emissions Strategy GIRO-ZERO
Description_new:
During the first 19 days of implementation of the project, the first contacts with possible network members and advisory board were made. 
This initial key progress in the network construction included:

a)	Discussions within the Giro Zero team on possible advisory board members and Giro Zero network members. 
b)	Phone conversation with Julio Villalobos, Universidad Andrés Bello, Chile on recommendations for advisory members from Latin America.
c)	Phone conversation with Alan McKinnon, Kühne Logistics University, Germany on possible advisory board members and Giro Zero network members.

The first board meeting has been scheduled for the beginning of May 2021.
Result_Title: GIRO Zero Network established among key stakeholders that could potentially benefit the sector as a whole by easing measurement, reporting and verification (MRV) of emissions generated within the sector, as well as data sharing among stakeholders
Description:
The starting point of the network is the steering committee of the project, which include members of COLFECAR, the Colombian government, and international experts. The network will be allowed to grow endogenously from our workshops, seminars and events. That is, the network will grow throughout the project. 
Quarterly reports to be presented.

2022 Q1-final GIRO Zero network event: 
The network will be formalized in the final event of the project, when stakeholders that have actively interacted with the project, and have a large influence in the sector, will be invited. The final event will focus on key decision makers, will have a minimum of 20 key stakeholders and will be streamed online for the public.

Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description_new:
1). First update of the socialisation/meetings to strengthen the tourism and conservation network. In 2021-Q1 two relevant meetings with specific tasks and agreements with each party were achieved:

- WWF: meeting with the COO and the organization leaders  that work on nature tourism at the project prioritized destinations. The main conclusions of this meeting are: i) they agree to be part of the group of experts that will create the conservation, leadership and sustainable tourism pensum. ii) They also agree to cooperate in the destinations where both organizations have interventions, to assure that there are no duplicate efforts and to share information, contacts, among others. 

- Humboldt Biological Research Institute: This institute have great interest in participating in the monitoring component of this project, they find very useful this pilot since it links monitoring processes with the tourism sector, the marketing strategy and the possibility to generate new benefits for this organizations, in order to assure monitoring process over time. Highlights include: i) it´s clear for both parties that it is key that the project generates public information of the monitoring processes in order to be integrated in the Institute information systems. ii) The Humboldt Institute is a very valuable ally and can contribute, with knowledge and experience, in the implementation of Monitoring systems. iii) The Humboldt Institute will define in which moment of the process they will intervene and contribute, based on Awake's work plan, for what both parties will work on that in the next weeks.  iv) It is also agreed that it is very important to participate and connect  monitoring process results with the platforms that Humboldt Institute uses, to contribute and enhance the information of Colombia´s biodiversity.
Result_Title: Socialisation of the project and come to agreements with key local authorities and key stakeholders in each of the destinations to help potentiate the results and impact of the project
Description:
At least 15 virtual or on-site meetings to socialize the project and at least 10 written agreements with the stakeholders.

This component seeks to:

- Socialise and articulate the project with local authorities and key actors with a presence in the destinations (NGOs, private companies, national government), to ensure the non-duplication of efforts  and seek the support of these key actors not only in the execution of the project, but also in the sustainability of the interventions in the long term.

- Create agreements with local authorities (alcaldías y gobernaciones) and other key stakeholders that have incidence in the prioritised destinations of the project (NGO’s, private entities, government entities, among others), that will allow the commitment of these actors regarding their support and contributions to the project, agreements regarding the contributions of these organisations to tourism or conservation processes in the destinations; and agreements on working in coordination with specific components of the project (example: training processes, ecosystem monitoring processes, etc.).

The project’s goal is to create 10 written agreements with clear commitments regarding: support given to the project, exchange of information that enhances the actions of these actors and the actions of the project regarding tourism and conservation, articulation for the work on specific components and interventions of the project, actions or clear resources that will be invested and given for tourism and conservation purposes, in each territory, by these entities.

In order to do so, there will be meetings with leaders of each organisation or key stakeholder (they can be on-site or virtual meetings), where we will socialise the project. Then there will be periodic follow ups through mail, calls or other meetings, until reaching final written documents that state all commitments between Awake and each actor.

There will be quarterly updates on these meetings.

Project: City of Johannesburg Electric Vehicle Readiness Support
Description_new: Online session with key staff from departments of climate change and air quality, electricity & transport. The workshop aim was to provide an overview of the Johannesburg's EV readiness Support Programme and the local context in relation to electric vehicle development, including existing policies and programmes at the national and local level. It also provided  an opportunity for each department to align this project with their department's goals and work plans. It also provided an opportunity to align with the national Department of Transport's Green Transport Strategy.
Result_Title: First of four capacity building sessions with CoJ EV steering committee and relevant national stakeholders
Description: Online session with key staff from relevant City departments, which provides an update of project progress and learnings to date, but also provide a platform for discussion / guidance. As such, national stakeholders may be invited, topic dependent. The sessions aim to ensure continued buy-in from all relevant stakeholders, alignment with City goals, while also acting as a knowledge-exchange and problem-solving hub. As such, this will be a flexible space that will include topics, as they arise, which may not fall neatly within other project activities / outputs, but has been highlighted as a need as the project progresses.

Project: Sustainable Tourism Enhancement Project - Phase 2: Boosting conservation and emissions reduction through tourism and technology
Description_new:
An identification of new organisations and updated the information of those involved in the first phase of the project was made through phone calls with each organisation’s leader and recollected general information about the organisation. The project was socialised and identified if
they were interested in the project or not. An official communication was also sent to the organisations with the project summary and commitments to detail the project information.
As a result, 26 of the organisations that participated in the first phase of the project have agreed to continue and have shown interest and commitment. The other 40 organisations showed no interest in participating, mainly, because of the impact that COVID-19 has had on the tourism sector and therefore in their business or due to other personal reasons.
Research and mapping of new tourism organisations was made, presenting 58 new businesses that have shown interest in participating in the project, for a total of 82 organisations
identified.
During the scouting for new organisations, new destinations in different departments have also been selected, such as: Trinidad and San Luis de Palenque in Casanare, Barbacoas in Narino, Cajibio in Cauca, Vistahermosa and San Martín in Meta, Mocoa and Villagarzón in Putumayo, and Cali and El Cerrito in Valle del Cauca.

Project: Innovative financial mechanisms for the transition to cleaner bus fleets in Colombia
Description_new: A first version of the financial modelling results for the total cost of ownership of e-fleets including the participation of utilities and public sector was developed and submitted to TransMilenio during the first quarter of 2020, together with a guideline of the electric vehicle test protocol. Officials from Transmilenio agreed with the parameters and results of the financial analysis and a final version of the modelling is planned for May 2020. WRI developed and delivered the Test Protocol document for electric vehicles, which was approved by the TransMilenio technical team.
Result_Title: Development of a new financing model
Description: Development of a new financing model that reassesses the cost structure of investments in the new electric bus fleet. The development of the model will include a feasibility study of using a private sector financing mechanism and a guideline for an electric vehicle test protocol.

Project: Innovative financial mechanisms for the transition to cleaner bus fleets in Colombia

WRI continued working with TransMilenio staff and other relevant government officials online as well, to ensure a long-lasting relationship with local stakeholders. 
WRI also worked to renew their standing MOU with the City of Bogota.

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
Q2 2020
WWF has produced a preliminary version of a GHG guide and related calculation spreadsheets. These preliminary materials have been shared with WWF consultants, which are the technical liaisons with the cities and are responsible for encouraging its use in the target cities of Medellín, Cali, Montería and Pereira. 
Q3 2020
The final version of the guide and tools, as well as final recommendations on how to use them, was made completely public in September 2020.
Result_Title: Use the updated GHG emissions inventories guide
Description: Recommendation to the mayoralties of the cities of Cali, Pereira, Monteria, and Medellin to make use of the new GHG emission inventories guide for the update of their cities' inventories and for the design of MRV systems in the transport sector

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
By the end of 2020, GHG inventories had been completely updated for Medellín, Montería, Cali and Pereira with the information collected by technical personnel of WWF and the collaboration of government personnel in each city. 
Moreover, MRV systems for the eight selected transport projects were already designed and socialized among key stakeholders, and technical trainings were conducted in all the cities. The pending activity is the registration of the projects in RENARE, which will quantify their contributions to the NDCs.
Result_Title: Mayoralties implement the updated GHG inventories guide
Description: The mayoralties of the cities of Cali, Pereira, Monteria, and Medellin implement the new GHG emission inventories guide:  they upd for the update of their cities' inventories and the design and implementation of MRV systems in the transport sector

Project: Catalysing local implementation of climate action: unleashing the potential of non-state actors.
Description_new:
By mid-2020, WWF consultants, which are the technical liaisons with the government personnel in each city started working in the update of GHG inventories for each city. 
Furthermore, the four cities made the selection of the transport projects for which MRV systems were to be designed and implemented. The transport projects for which MRV systems will be designed are projects currently in implementation (since 2015 and after) which have high mitigation potential.
The list of the projects is as follows: 
Medellín 
- Tranvía de Ayacucho: 4-kilometre light rail project currently in operation. 
- Metro Cable: Cable car project comprising two lines and 44 cabins. 
Cali 
- Mio Cable: Cable car with 51 cabins. 
- Mio Electric Buses: 424 New electric buses for the city’s fleet. 
Pereira 
- Mega Bici: Public Bicycle system with 110 bicycles and 7 docking stations. 
- Mega Cable: Cable car project comprising one line and 51 cabins. Construction to be finalized in 2020. 
Montería 
- Businú phase 1: River transportation system along the Sinú river. 
- Bicisinú: Public bicycle system already in operation with more than 10,000 users
Result_Title: Mayoralties adopt the updated GHG inventories guide
Indicator: Int. Out 3. 'Adoption of recommendation for other action'
Description: The mayoralties of the cities of Cali, Pereira, Monteria, and Medellin adopt the new GHG emission inventories guide for the update of their cities' inventories and the design and implementation of MRV systems in the transport sector
