Project: Institutional Capacity Building Framework Program to accelerate adoption of electric mobility in public transport in India
Result_Title: Develop  Kakinada  Electric  Mobility  Network  (KEMN)
Description:
Output: A high quality app with at-least 1,000 users enrolled. 
A KEMN app will provide information on green mobility, provide a group chat 
facility, feature visual media associated with green mobility and periodically 
host quick tests of knowledge of the science behind green mobility, the 
extent of adoption world-wide and the range of products available in the 
market. 
IMPORTANCE 
Citizens are both owners of green mobility products and users of green 
mobility services. Creating a community of those who are committed to 
green mobility technology over the long term is essential to bulk up the 
demand for such products and services and to initiate the regulatory changes 
which would remove the barriers to change. Periodic tests and surveys will 
help ascertain if the anticipated penetration of the programme into the 
online space has created the much-needed noise for green mobility in rapidly 
developing urban cities. 
TARGET BENEFICIARIES 
The KEMN will host all interested participants of the skills development and 
knowledge communication programs on a virtual platform. Subject to COVID-19 restrictions, physical meetings and events may also be possible.
Implementor: Research Triangle Institute Global India Private Limited

Project: Institutional Capacity Building Framework Program to accelerate adoption of electric mobility in public transport in India
Result_Title: Training for  Entrepreneurs  interested in E-mobility
Description:
Output: 100 entrepreneurs/businesses trained 
This output will focus on the supply side of e-mobility and provide specific 
training to entrepreneurs and businesses interested in establishing and or 
expanding in products, equipment, services and solutions. 
One day training program covering following modules to be delivered 2 times 
during the year: 
1. Technology awareness about electric vehicles 
2. Market potential and business models for e-vehicles 
3. Commercial and financial skills 
This training session will benefit entrepreneurs and businesses in regard to 
upskilling them with the best business practices prevalent in the industry 
today. The session will also focus on upgraded and refined modules on how 
to establish and thrive in the e-vehicle industry, key technological advents 
and the fundamentals of commercial and financial ethics of the upkeep of 
the business. It will be delivered ONLINE and the courses shall be available 
offline to be reviewed by the trainees. The same will be available on the 
KEMN app to encourage active participation in open dialogue. 
IMPORTANCE: Sound entrepreneurial skills and healthy business ethics will 
help ensure the ‘self-sustainability’ aspect of the EV infrastructure set up in 
Kakinada. They will be able to attract more investments if they’re aware of 
the prevalent industry practices and also adapt to diverse business 
environments. Entrepreneurs in the EV market will further drive the 
ecosystem towards attaining success in replicability of the model, in not only 
Indian cities, but also other countries.
Implementor: Research Triangle Institute Global India Private Limited

Project: Institutional Capacity Building Framework Program to accelerate adoption of electric mobility in public transport in India
Result_Title: Feasibility  Report and Plan  for E-Buses in  Kakinada
Description:
Though Kakinada was sanctioned bridge capital funds for deployment of 50 
electric buses, the financial crunch at state and city level enhanced due to 
COVID-19 has resulted in deferring of procurement of buses in the 
immediate period. While the city is committed to buses in the long term, this 
period would be utilised for creation of business, operations and 
implementation plan, demand and supply traction, and capacity 
development. This will be reflected in the following manner 
(a) Assessment of the current bus regulations and operations 
mechanisms for state and cities. 
(b) State and city level electric bus adoption policy and programme 
(c) Validate the existing data on the identified city routes and support 
infra 
(d) Create the business, operating and implementation plan by  (i) Finalising the creation of profit/ accounting centre under the aegis 
of public sector operating service provider at state/ city level, as the case 
maybe 
 (ii) The PPP potential, operating models, structure, procurement, block 
cost and revenue estimates, gap and budgetary commitment 
 (iii) Develop a business structure and run it through the regulatory 
institution to resolve bottlenecks 
 (iv) Financing mechanism under banks, NBFCs, bilateral and multilateral 
arrangements 
 (v) The best practices as relevant to the state/ city covering salient 
aspects of RFPs, O&M and Concession Agreements 
 (vi) Overview of social and economic benefits 
The entire exercise would entail extensive interaction with the stakeholders 
comprising of political champions and bureaucratic government officials 
including regulators, energy, infra and investment department(s), OEM 
product and service providers, banking and financing institutions and above
all the citizens and commuters of Kakinada including school going children, 
females, etc.
Implementor: Research Triangle Institute Global India Private Limited

Project: Institutional Capacity Building Framework Program to accelerate adoption of electric mobility in public transport in India
Result_Title: Scheme for e-rickshaws in  Kakinada  launched
Description:
The present 3,000 auto rickshaws are amenable and quick win for migration 
(including retrofitting) to electric. This would create an entire ecosystem and 
employment opportunities. The scheme will be delivered by UMTC, our 
partner: 
(a) Study of the existing regulatory, operating and financing mechanism 
including the best practices of State(s) Electric Vehicle Policies 
(b) Focused group discussion with the ecosystem of government 
officials (city and transport permit regulators and elected reps), commuters 
(age and gender), MSME operators, e rickshaw manufacturers/ product 
providers, banking and financing institutions 
(c) Identify challenges mitigating measures 
(d) Organise a demonstration of the products, governing specifications, 
reliability and efficiencies 
(e) Assess the demand and supply side of fleet including charging infra 
and energy requirement and business structure 
(f) Develop a business structure and financial model and run it with the 
regulatory and financial institutions to resolve bottlenecks 
(g) Prepare the first cut of the scheme and open house sessions for 
comments 
(h) Finalise the scheme and prepare the draft notification 
(i) Finalise the notification and launch the scheme
Implementor: Research Triangle Institute Global India Private Limited

Project: Institutional Capacity Building Framework Program to accelerate adoption of electric mobility in public transport in India
Result_Title: Capacity  Development  of Power Sector  Stakeholder
Description:
Output: 50 engineers and officials from local distribution company, 
contractors, regulatory commission and energy department trained 
This output will focus on developing a dedicated training module (duration 
1.0 day) covering following aspects: 
1. Design of power distribution network to support charging infrastructure. 
2. Regulatory incentives and tariff structure for charging infrastructure. 
3. Smart metering and optimization 
4. Customer engagement 
We will do a mini training needs assessment ahead of designing the module 
to understand the context and level of knowledge in the beneficiary 
stakeholders. 
Our approach to designing this training module will be to review 
international best practices and customize them for local policy, regulatory 
and technical context. 
We will ensure that the training program includes case studies, hands on 
exercise and field visits as appropriate and relevant. 
Additional resources will be provided directly at the training program and 
through the proposed KEMN to ensure continued learning. 
Based on interest, we will also support advanced learning options to select 
employees (maximum 5) on a cost share basis. 
We will deliver two classroom sessions for 25-30 number of targeted 
audiences. One such event will be delivered in Kakinada and other maybe in 
Hyderabad/Kakinada depending on interest from beneficiaries.
Implementor: Research Triangle Institute Global India Private Limited

Project: Institutional Capacity Building Framework Program to accelerate adoption of electric mobility in public transport in India
Result_Title: Capacity  Development  of Banking and  Financial  Institutions
Description:
Output: 50 officials from local banks, financial institutions and Non-bank 
financing companies, financial advisors, insurance companies etc. trained 
This output will focus on developing a dedicated training module (duration 
1.0 day) for stakeholders in financial industry to enable them to efficiently 
provide capital for investments in electric vehicles and related charging 
infrastructure. 
Since the technology is new and evolving, it is difficult for financial sector to 
price the risks involved. The approach therefore is to raise the cost of capital 
to manage uncertainty and unknowns. This leads to interest rates that are 
too high from business financial sustainability perspective and therefore 
discourages entrepreneurs and business to invest. 
The training program will focus on sensitizing financial industry participants 
to the technical, operational and commercial aspects of electric vehicles. This 
will ensure lower cost of capital and efficient processing of proposals for 
businesses wanting to invest in the space. 
Training module will include following themes: 
1. Why electric vehicles? 
2. Technical and operational characteristics and performance 
3. Safety, Risks and related considerations 
4. Policy, regulatory and programmatic considerations 
We will invite manufactures and suppliers of electric vehicles and charging 
infrastructure as experts/panellists in these sessions to 
We will deliver two classroom sessions for 25-30 number of targeted 
audiences. One such event will be delivered in Kakinada and other maybe in 
Hyderabad/Kakinada depending on interest from beneficiaries.
Implementor: Research Triangle Institute Global India Private Limited

Project: Institutional Capacity Building Framework Program to accelerate adoption of electric mobility in public transport in India
Result_Title: Training for  Technical  Student and  Employees
Description:
Output: 500 students and employees trained 
Three one day modules will be delivered: 
1. Technical students in Industrial Training Institutes and engineering colleges 
2. Employees in Auto industry such as workshops 
3. Auto and cab drivers 
The course shall contain modules on maintenance of motors and batteries, 
store management and hands-on practical training for an enhanced learning 
experience. It aims to equip the vital link of this chain with industry-ready 
technical and managerial skills. As Kakinada is a Tier-II IT city, it enjoys a 
sophisticated crowd of students and employees with a certain knack for 
technology and its advanced variants. The modules will be delivered ONLINE 
and the courses shall be available offline to be reviewed by the trainees. The 
same will be available on the KEMN app to encourage active participation in 
open dialogue. 
We will collaborate with local NGOs so that labs and practical training 
sessions can be set up for each and every trainee of this activity. 
IMPORTANCE: Apart from setting up base for engaging entrepreneurs and 
businesses in the EV infrastructure development in Kakinada, it is also 
important to work towards sustaining it. Keen ITI and engineering students, 
employees in the industry and auto and cab drivers form the backbone of 
this infrastructure. It is necessary to provide them with the best upskilling 
training modules, so that they can adapt to it rapidly. Due to the prolonged 
setback the auto-industry, as a whole, has experienced in the past 6 months, 
quality-enhancement, reduced workload and 24*7 output is the need of the 
hour.
Implementor: Research Triangle Institute Global India Private Limited

Project: Utility led smart electric vehicle charging for demand response and grid management in New Delhi, India
Result_Title: Technical  demonstration of  a utility-led  electric vehicle  smart charging  implementation  for 3-, and 4- wheelers
Description:
The output of this phase of the project is a technical 
implementation and a proof of concept demand response 
with EV charging. The project will develop a methodology, 
identify and implement a technical solution and run 
experiments and collect data at ten to fifty 3-wheeler 
charging locations, and three to five 4-wheeler charging 
host locations. Suitable host sites will be jointly identified 
by BYPL and eDRV’s technical team. The project does not 
seek funding for installing hardware from UK PACT, and 
will identify other sources or use existing hardware to 
generate this output.
The tasks in output 1 engage the EV chargers and set up 
real-time communication with the utility’s distribution 
management system. The eDRV engineering team will 
identify and construct a suitable technology link based on 
global best practices and in consultation with BYPL. Once 
the system is implemented, charging hosts will receive 
real-time trigger events from the distribution utility, 
causing the charging process to be automatically 
modified, demonstrating a shift or instant reduction in the 
energy demand from EV charging activity. eDRV will 
collect and jointly analyse performance data to evaluate 
responses from charging hosts, develop insights and make 
recommendations, and create the basis of further 
economic analysis for the subsequent outputs (2) and (3) 
of the project.
The goal of this output is to establish the pilot, which can 
demonstrate the viability and technical requirements for 
implementing demand response for 3w and 4w charging. 
The data will be used to conduct further technical and 
economic analysis for deferred infrastructure costs for 
BSES. This will determine potential savings and 
environmental impact.

Project: Utility led smart electric vehicle charging for demand response and grid management in New Delhi, India
Result_Title: Validate grid  benefits for  distribution  companies, and  evaluate potential  savings and  economic benefits  from EV demand  response  management
Description:
Output 2 will include gathering specific information from 
the technical demonstration in output 1, and use the 
findings as inputs for an economic model to assess the 
overall demand management potential of managed 
charging. CEEW's team of expert economic modelers will 
combine information from a variety of sources such as 
market growth forecasts, policy targets for electric 
mobility, and inputs on costs to the utility and end 
consumers to quantify state-wide and economy-wide 
economic benefits. 
The economic analysis will use experimental data from 
the pilot to evaluate the potential effect of a variety of 
price-based and behavior-based interventions on the 
utility's plans for peak clipping, load shifting, valley filling, 
and energy conservation under future scenarios of high 
EV penetration. Data will also be used to evaluate the 
economic benefits from advanced EV charging 
management and its revenue and savings potential for 
utilities. Information gathered will be delivered in the 
form of a report. 
Managed charging demonstrations internationally have 
shown significant benefits to utilities. The project team 
will engage other utilities, policymakers, and charging 
network operators to disseminate their body of work. The 
evidence will help other utilities make informed decisions 
and play a key role in advancing electric mobility charging 
solutions.

Project: Utility led smart electric vehicle charging for demand response and grid management in New Delhi, India
Result_Title: Distribution  companies,  regulators, and the  broader set of  power sector  stakeholders will  gain access to pilot  insights through  regular  workshops,  publications and  interactions.
Description:
This task will primarily consist of quarterly events and 
outreach, spread through the course of the project and 
led by the CEEW communications team. This will be used 
as an avenue of reaching out to a wide range of 
stakeholders including policymakers, utilities, charging 
network operators and other industry professionals 
through a combination of open webinars and invite-only 
workshops.

Project: Utility led smart electric vehicle charging for demand response and grid management in New Delhi, India
Result_Title: Develop a  conceptual  framework for  regulation on time  of use pricing to  incentivise EV  charging during  periods when the  grid has higher  renewable energy  penetration and  disincentivize charging during  peak demand  periods so that the  system..
Description:
The output will be a study that outlines the technical 
feasibility and the financial savings or benefits that will 
accrue to the electricity utility if smart charging is 
combined with differential pricing to manage and 
smoothen electricity demand curves, as well as 
synchronise renewable energy injections into the grid 
system with EV charging peaks. This study will enable 
electric utilities to make an evidence-based case for the 
need for policy and regulatory support for differential 
pricing, as well as layout the regulatory and policy 
roadmap for Central and State governments (and 
regulators) to facilitate this. This will benefit consumers en masse as the overall financial health of utilities will 
improve, with the benefits being passed on to consumers, 
charging network operators and EV drivers. It will also 
engage end consumers and households in India’s energy 
transition, making it a demand-driven transition rather 
than just a supply-side government procurement push.

Project: Strategy and Action Plan for Electrification of Public Transport and Intermediate Public Transport in the Indian Cities
Result_Title: Baseline  Diagnostic  Study Report
Description:
The first output of the project will be a baseline diagnostic study 
report. This would include a review of international experiences and 
business models for implementing electric mobility initiatives, 
especially from developing countries in the world. 
This would also include case-city specific outputs as outlined below: 
Ahmedabad (Public Transport) 
The diagnostic study report in case of Ahmedabad concentrates on 
analyzing the existing situation analysis of public transport, service 
levels of bus operation, identification of challenges both from the 
perspective of operators, and users including women, low income 
groups etc. The diagnostic report will also include the study of climate 
commitments at the national and state level, EV policy framework, 
funding availability, and city initiative and strategy towards 
accelerating electrification of public transport in Ahmedabad. Further, 
it will detail out stakeholders, their roles and responsibilities, key 
challenges in smooth transition to electric buses. 
Mehsana (Intermediate Public Transport) 
The diagnostic study report for Mehsana will include all the 
components discussed above for Ahmedabad. Additionally, the report 
will include the review of the regulatory framework for transforming 
the existing unregulated IPT system, the innovative business models 
that are scalable and financially sustainable for all stakeholders in the 
uptake of EVs in IPT mode segment. 
This output will be delivered to key stakeholders such as state 
administrative offices, local government and PT agencies, and bus 
operators. The report would also outline specific concerns of different 
user groups including low-income and women groups. The report is 
extremely essential as it acts as a base for the second stage of the 
project i.e. development of action plan and strategy for case cities. 
This output will be taken as input for strategizing the 
recommendations for seamless shift to electric mobility.

Project: Strategy and Action Plan for Electrification of Public Transport and Intermediate Public Transport in the Indian Cities
Result_Title: Creation of  stakeholder  networks
Description:
For widespread penetration of electric vehicles, comprehensive 
participation from stakeholders such as public agencies, Original 
Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs), energy providers, Power 
Distribution Companies (DISCOMS), bus/IPT operators and users is 
critical. Therefore, the next output of the project is focused on 
creating stakeholder networks and strengthening the existing 
collaborations to create a buy-in on the electrification strategy. 
The outputs will be: 
• Formation of Advisory groups with representations from the state 
and local stakeholder agencies in Ahmedabad and Mehsana 
• Formation of Working groups with NGOs (working for welfare of 
women and marginalised sections), local representatives and local 
authority in the respective cities 
The output will help in 
• Mainstreaming energy sector into urban transport planning by their 
inclusion in strategizing e-bus procurement plans and identification of 
depots/ terminals for electrification. 
• Strengthening technical capacities through workshops for bus 
agencies with OEMs as they can impart a better understanding of 
electric vehicles, their maintenance and performance 
• Strengthening ties between existing public transport agencies i.e. 
AMTS (Ahmedabad Municipal Transport Service) that provide city bus 
operation in Ahmedabad and Ahmedabad Janmarg Ltd that is 
dedicated for BRTS (bus rapid transit systems) operation in the city. 
• Mainstreaming the IPT system to operate like a PT system in 
Mehsana 
• Engagement with user groups including women, urban poor, 
differently-abled in the planning process for preparation of an 
inclusive PT electrification strategy

Project: Strategy and Action Plan for Electrification of Public Transport and Intermediate Public Transport in the Indian Cities
Result_Title: Bus/IPT  Electrification  Strategy and  Action Plan
Description:
This report will present the Electrification Strategy and Action plan for 
the case cities of Ahmedabad and Mehsana till 2026. 
Based on the Diagnostic Report and discussion with the city and state 
level agencies (Advisory Group), alternative electric scenarios would 
be developed. To evaluate these scenarios, an Assessment Framework 
will be formulated which would consider the following: 
a) Impact on GHG emission reduction 
b) Access improvements for women and urban poor 
c) Evaluation of EV market 
d) Passenger demand analysis 
e) Charging Technology Assessment 
f) Grid impacts 
g) Financial and Institutional capacities 
Evaluation of the scenarios would help in defining the future 
electrification strategy for PT/IPT in the two cities. This strategy would 
outline: 
• Business and operating models for electrification of PT in 
Ahmedabad and IPT in Mehsana. 
• Policy and regulatory interventions to facilitate e-vehicle adoption 
• Electric bus fleet type, charging type, land and depot and charging
infrastructure requirement 
• Electricity infrastructure development for IPT vehicles based on 
power flow analysis 
• Fleet deployment policy and routing strategies based on location of 
charging infrastructure and low-income areas in the city 
• Strategies for improving the accessibility of public transport in 
particular for low income groups and women along with measures for 
inclusion of women in the work force 
In addition, the report would also present a monitoring and evaluation 
framework for the project so that the outcome could be monitored 
over the next five years. 
This output will be delivered to key stakeholders such as state 
administrative offices, local government and PT agencies, and bus 
operators. The output will work as a guide to facilitate a greener and 
sustainable urban transport future for case cities. This will provide 
inputs to the state government and city authorities for promoting 
electric mobility through various schemes and programs and actions.

Project: Strategy and Action Plan for Electrification of Public Transport and Intermediate Public Transport in the Indian Cities
Result_Title: Knowledge  Products and  Dissemination
Description:
A project website would be prepared for communication and 
dissemination of project outputs and knowledge products. A range of 
capacity building and training modules would be prepared and 
delivered as part of this project. This would include sensitization and 
awareness workshop for city authority, bus agencies, auto association 
(Mehsana), NGOs on policy scenario and benefits of electrification of 
bus/IPT fleet and how it would bring in improved service quality and 
address climate change. A training of auto drivers in Mehsana on the 
vehicle types, charging technology, cost analysis and business models 
would have to be undertaken to ensure their buy-in. Another training for bus agencies in Ahmedabad on EV technology, depot planning, 
operating model and bus deployment would be essential for building 
their capacities. 
Also, a national level workshop for dissemination of study findings to 
ensure scaling up of this initiative and replication across other similar 
cities in India would be organized. Lastly, research papers that deal 
with different aspects of the project – policy, survey design and 
analysis, stakeholder engagements and consultations, technical 
analysis would also be prepared for conference presentations.

Project: South Africa Skill share: Hydrogen Society Roadmap
Result_Title: M&E mentoring sessions with senior officials
Description:
Mentoring sessions with senior officials from the Department of Science and Innovation who will be responsible for the implementation of the Hydrogen Society Roadmap (quantity and frequency still to be determined).

The goal will be to support the roll out of the TOC and to ensure that M&E is not only embedded in the roadmap itself but is also taken seriously, in terms of learning and improvement, by key stakeholders (state and non-state). An assessment of the usefulness of the mentoring sessions will be undertaken to see if they have helped support the roll out of the ToC and the MEL framework.

Project: South Africa Skill share: Hydrogen Society Roadmap
Result_Title: Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning (MEL) framework for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap
Description:
Building on all the capacity-building work developed by this skill share, creation of a draft MEL Framework, schematic and report which provides analysis of any existing gaps and recommendations to resolve these.

Reports will describe the draft MEL Framework and actions to be taken by whom. It will include an analysis of gaps (e.g. relating to data and their sources) and recommendations to address them.  It will include the intended outcomes (including GESI) and MEL’s role in ensuring their delivery.

Project: South Africa Skill share: Hydrogen Society Roadmap
Result_Title: Theory of Change (ToC) for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap
Description: Building on all the capacity-building work developed by this skill share, creation of Theory of Change (ToC) for the Hydrogen Society Roadmap, with an accompanying report explaining the ToC in detail as well as the anticipated economic, social (including GESI), environmental and climate outcomes from Hydrogen Society Roadmap and how they will be generated. The schematic will provide an accessible high-level overview.

Project: South Africa Skill share: Hydrogen Society Roadmap
Result_Title: Recommendations for best practice in establishing MEL systems for the national hydrogen strategy
Description: Bilateral meetings and workshops (webinar) will draw on a range of MEL frameworks/best practice supporting M&E of the ToC, and will be attended by senior officials and by operational/specialist/technical personnel. The high-level workshop will discuss KPIs and key evaluation questions (including for GESI) and will establish MEL governance and how and by whom MEL outputs will be used.

Project: Skill share: Colombia Climate Physical Risks and Financial Stability
Result_Title: Identify transmission channels and recommend scenario test options to show how physical climate risks affect financial stability in Colombia
Description:
Lead discussions with the Banco de la Republica and Superintendencia Financiera to assess climate projections and the available data on transmission risks for Colombia. 
The goal is to create a comprehensive list of possible transmission channels and establish recommended scenarios for how to perform top-down climate stress tests. These will assess the impact of physical risks associated with climate change in the Colombian financial system and help the Banco de la Republica to identify ways to improve, better quantify and assess the impact of climate related risks on the economy and on financial stability.

Project: Skill share: Colombia Climate Physical Risks and Financial Stability
Result_Title: Capacity building workshop to inform and upskill wider teams within the Banco de la Republica and Superintendencia Financiera on the importance of understanding the impact of physical climate risks
Description:
Capacity building support for the teams at the Banco de la Republica and Superintendencia Financiera to help them better quantify and assess the impact of climate related risks on the economy and on financial stability, deliver the best outcomes and build knowledge within their teams. 
To achieve this, the support needed is:
•	Workshop to inform and upskill wider teams within the Banco de la Republica and Superintendencia Financiera on the importance of understanding the impact of physical risks. The consultants will agree exact dates and participants with the Banco de la Republica and Superintendencia Financiera towards the end of the skill-share.

Project: Skill share: Colombia Climate Physical Risks and Financial Stability
Result_Title: Provide inputs into the Central Bank's top-down stress testing methodology to map the effects of the materialisation of climate change physical risks to the Colombian financial system
Description:
Lead discussions with the Banco de la Republica and Superintendencia Financiera to explore statistical approaches that could be adopted in order to perform stress tests to the Colombian financial system that assess financial institutions’ resilience to the materialisation of physical risks derived from climate change.
The goal is to create a top-down stress testing methodology which maps the effects of the materialisation of climate change physical risks to the Colombian financial system.

Project: Action Plan for Electrification of Two Wheelers in Jakarta
Result_Title: Action plan for electrification of  ride hailing  motorcycle
Description:
The project will produce a roadmap and timetable 
document for electrifying ride-hailing motorcycles. The 
document includes recommendations on e-motorcycle 
scenarios, policy barriers and recommendations, charging 
infrastructure, financial and business model and grid 
supply plan developed with State Power Company (PLN). 
The output’s components will include:
Data collection and plan alignment: ITDP in collaboration 
with stakeholders will conduct primary and secondary 
data collection and surveys and disaggregate by gender, 
age, and income where applicable. Working in 
collaboration with the stakeholders will raise their 
capacity and buy-in for the project.
Stakeholder consultation through participatory workshop: 
ITDP will conduct consultation through participatory 
workshops with stakeholders. In addition, GESI issues are 
addressed in the planning documents and 
implementation and a participatory workshop series will 
be conducted with women and marginalized communities 
representatives.
Align the proposed recommendations with stakeholders’ 
current plans and policies. 
Document development: ITDP team will conduct regular 
coordination meetings with the Transport agency and ride 
hailing operators to co-develop the action plan and 
timetable document. 
TCO and environmental benefit calculation tool 
development: A calculation tool will be developed with 
stakeholders to project the benefits of electrification and 
calculate TCO.
The findings and report will be presented to the Ministry 
of Transportation as inputs to the roadmap and timetable 
of e-motorcycles in Indonesia.
The output is important as it will be used for ride-hailing 
operators to set phases, create timetables, and prepare 
the mechanisms and investments needed to electrify their fleets. The city government will use the output to prepare 
the regulation and supporting policies needed. The 
national government and other cities could also adopt this 
roadmap and utilize the calculation tool. The roadmap will 
also help ensure alignment between supporting 
infrastructure provision and fleet deployment.

Project: Action Plan for Electrification of Two Wheelers in Jakarta
Result_Title: Complete street  design guideline  accommodating  e-motorcycle  uptake
Description:
Development of complete street design in response to emotorcycles adoption focusing on road safety and 
accessibility for marginalized communities. This may 
include:
-Where e-motorcycles fit in the transportation ecosystem
-Differentiating e-bikes and e-motorcycles, through 
weight, power, and speed limitations, etc.
-Parking regulations for e-motorcycles and motorcycles in 
general
-Charging regulations
-How to address congestion with two-wheelers
The components will include:
Issue identification. ITDP with stakeholders will identify 
road safety issues related to motorcycles through desk 
research and a participatory workshop. Active 
participation from women, people with disabilities, the 
elderly, and other marginalized communities as road 
users shall be ensured and the data gathered will be 
disaggregated by sex, disability, age groups, and income 
level whenever applicable.
Document development. A complete street design 
guidebook addressing the identified issues will be 
produced. Regular discussion with the Transport Agency 
and Public Works Agency of Jakarta will be conducted to 
ensure the applicability of the recommendations. The 
guideline will be disseminated to the Government of 
Jakarta, BPTJ as the transport authority of the Greater 
Jakarta Area, and other city governments. 
The large-scale uptake of e-motorcycles will pose new 
challenges to road users since several segments of e-motorcycles may fall into a grey area between bicycles 
and motorcycles. A guide on street design is important to 
provide a clear classification of the e-motorcycles in the 
road user ecosystem and to ensure accessibility for all 
road users.

Project: Action Plan for Electrification of Two Wheelers in Jakarta
Result_Title: lectric twowheeler  supporting policy  and e-mobility  policy
Description:
The output will include two main components:
-Conducting a review on the current national and local 
transport, energy, and environmental planning documents 
and other relevant policies. This will include fiscal and 
non-fiscal incentives, mandates of commercial fleet 
electrification and charging infrastructure provision, and 
environmental policies which directly and indirectly affect 
electrification. The review will also identify gaps and 
overlaps in the current policy landscape which may 
hamper electrification. 
-Producing a draft policy or a policy recommendation 
document to remove barriers and support e-motorcycle 
deployment by ride hailing operators, including a 
recommendation on the establishment of a local emobility task force and its working mechanisms. 
This will be accomplished through:
Desk research: ITDP will conduct a policy analysis to 
identify policy gaps and overlaps through a desk study. A 
benchmarking of bus fleet electrification policies from 
leading cities in commercial fleets electrification around 
the globe will also be conducted.
Stakeholder consultation: A stakeholder consultation 
event, in the form of an online workshop or one-on-one 
discussion sessions, will be conducted to verify the results 
of the desk study and benchmark analysis, identify further 
regulatory and implementation challenges met by the 
stakeholders, and identify options of policies to support 
the fleet electrification.
Document development: The resulting policy review and 
benchmarking study from the desk research, as well as the 
identified implementation challenges and policy options 
will become the inputs for the policy recommendation 
document. A set of policy recommendations for 
policymakers will be presented. Although there is a presidential decree to kickstart an 
electric vehicle acceleration program, no clear plans for 
motorcycle ride-hailing electrification exist despite its 
prominence in the sector. This output is crucial because 
without clear policy support, mandates for charging 
infrastructures, and fiscal and non-fiscal incentives, the 
deployment of e-motorcycle ride-hailing fleets will be 
hampered.

Project: Action Plan for Electrification of Two Wheelers in Jakarta
Result_Title: Report of  broader two  wheeler landscape in  Greater Jakarta
Description:
The project will produce a report on the current 
motorcycle landscape in Greater Jakarta and issues arising 
from public reliance on conventional motorcycles including GESI issues will be identified. The analysis will 
also underpin the benefits and challenges of phasing out 
conventional motorcycles and highlight the importance of 
transitioning ride-hailing fleets to electric as one of the 
first measures to encourage wider adoption of electric 
motorcycles.
The output’s components will include:
Data collection: A desk study to gather relevant statistical 
data and structured interviews with the ride hailing 
operators will be conducted to gather insights from fleet 
operator’s perspectives. Field surveys will also be 
conducted to complete missing data or update obsolete 
information . Wherever applicable, the data collected will 
be disaggregated by gender and income level. By working 
closely with Jakarta Transport Agency, the agency’s 
capacity in collecting relevant data for developing 
mobility plans will also be improved. 
Participatory workshops: To ensure GESI issues are 
addressed in the report, a participatory workshop series 
will be conducted with women and marginalized 
communities representatives to capture their perspective 
as ride-hailing and private motorcycle drivers, 
pedestrians, and other vulnerable road users affected by 
the large number of motorcycle on the road. 
Document development: A baseline report on the 
motorcycle landscape will be developed based on analysis 
of collected data and the stakeholder consultation 
workshop findings
The findings and report will be presented to Ride-hailing 
operator, Greater Jakarta Transport Agency (BPTJ) and 
Jakarta Transport Agency 
This output is critical to the project’s success because a 
baseline analysis on the current usage of motorcycles, the 
issues related to dependency to the mode, and the 
benefits and challenges of phasing out ICE motorcycles to 
electric is needed to raise initial awareness on motorcycle 
electrification and underpin the need for supporting 
policies among transport policymakers.

Project: Action Plan for Electrification of Two Wheelers in Jakarta
Result_Title: Inception and  Verification of  Technical  Assistance and  Work Plan
Description:
Within a week of contract award notification, a virtual 
kick-off meeting between UK PACT and ITDP will be 
organised to discuss and agree on key operating
modalities of the service delivery and communication 
protocols. 
ITDP will engage with stakeholders from the early stages 
and present the objective of the project, activities and the 
project timeline. ITDP will also become conversant with 
project personnel, city administration and other relevant 
stakeholders, to gather existing information and 
documentation. During the project preparation, the ride 
hailing operator, Transport Agency, Jakarta Government 
and other related stakeholders will provide information to 
ITDP in order to identify what relevant information is still 
needed to complete the project.
ITDP will use the inception phase to engage with all of the 
related stakeholders: Ride hailing operator, Transport 
Agency, Jakarta city government, PLN, and community 
groups. Stakeholder involvement from the beginning will 
allow for smooth knowledge transfer and ability to gain 
engagement for the project. 
This output is important because harnessing stakeholder 
involvement during the design stages will promote 
support and buy-in. It ensures the scheme delivered is 
acceptable to the stakeholders who need it most and 
should not stop at delivery. Targeted engagement can 
help address social exclusion and make the community 
aware that the developments will bring new access to 
opportunities and positive effects for their daily life.

Project: Building Capacity and an Action Plan to Scale up Transjakarta E buses
Result_Title: Comprehensive action plan to  significantly scale up electrification  of Transjakarta e-bus fleet
Description:
A scaling plan including a roadmap and timetable 
document will be produced. This includes an electric bus 
and charging infrastructure technical specification document, phased procurement plan, investment plan, 
and operational, charging and maintenance 
requirements. To support charging infrastructure, a grid 
supply plan will also be developed and communicated to 
the State Power Company (PLN). 
The output will be composed of the following:
-Data collection and plan alignment: In collaboration with 
Transjakarta’s counterpart project team ITDP will gather 
primary and secondary data through field surveys and 
from Transjakarta’s bus operators’ data (disaggregated 
by gender and income level where possible).
-Stakeholder consultation through participatory 
workshop: Participatory workshop series will be 
conducted with women and marginalized communities’ 
representatives and bus operators, with drivers often 
from low-income communities, with the objectives to:
 -Identify GESI issues in current bus service and service 
improvement opportunities
 -Identify the challenges and options of bus operators to 
implement electric mobility
 -Increase awareness, knowledge, and engagement 
from stakeholders
-Align proposed recommendations with Transjakarta’s 
current long-term corporate plan (“RJPP”) and city 
government. 
-Document development: Regular coordination meetings 
with Transjakarta to co-develop the action plan and 
timetable document. -Regular meetings with the PIU 
team to ensure that the recommendations are in line 
with institutions’ long-term objectives and adopted by 
them.
-Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) and environmental 
benefit calculation tool development: A calculation and 
decision-making tool (taking into account business and 
financial models) will be developed.
-The report will be presented to Transjakarta’s board of 
directors. 
This output is crucial to guiding Transjakarta’s electric 
bus scale up. The government of Jakarta will benefit by referring to the document when developing multi-year 
subsidy schemes and level of service agreement with 
Transjakarta. The roadmap will also help to ensure 
alignment between supporting infrastructure provision 
and fleet deployment.

Project: Building Capacity and an Action Plan to Scale up Transjakarta E buses
Result_Title: Inception and  Verification of  Technical  Assistance and  Work Plan
Description:
Within a week of contract award notification, a virtual 
kick-off meeting between UK PACT and ITDP will be 
organised to discuss and agree upon key operating 
modalities of service delivery and communication 
protocols.
ITDP will begin engagement with all relevant 
stakeholders at this stage. Involvement from the 
beginning of the project will allow us to effectively 
transfer knowledge and harness engagement. ITDP will 
present to the stakeholders on the objective of the 
project, specific activities, and project timeline. ITDP will 
also become conversant with the project, city 
administration and other relevant stakeholders, to 
gather any existing information and documentation. 
During the project preparation, Transjakarta, Jakarta 
Government, and other related stakeholders will provide 
information to ITDP so that we understand what 
information is still needed to complete the project.
This output is important because harnessing stakeholder 
involvement during the preliminary stages can promote 
support and buy-in, in addition to help incorporate the 
needs and wants of a wide array of groups. It ensures the 
scheme delivered is accessible and acceptable to the 
stakeholders who need it most and can be improved if 
necessary later on s. Targeted engagement can help 
address social exclusion and make the community aware 
that the developments will bring access to new 
opportunities and positive effects for their daily life.

Project: Building Capacity and an Action Plan to Scale up Transjakarta E buses
Result_Title: Policy  recommendations  for national and  local  policymakers to  ensure the  sustainability of  EV in public  transport fleet  from business,  energy, and  operations  aspects
Description:
The output will include two main components:
1. A review of the current transport, energy, and 
environmental planning documents for Jakarta bus fleet 
electrification. The review will also identify the gaps and 
overlaps in the current policy landscape which may 
hamper progress.
2. Producing a policy recommendation document to 
remove the barriers and support electric bus deployment 
in Jakarta, including a recommendation on the 
establishment of a local e-mobility task force and its 
mechanisms. 
The output will be composed of the following:
Desk research: ITDP will conduct a policy analysis to 
identify policy gaps and overlaps through a desk study. A 
benchmarking of bus fleet electrification policies from 
leading cities in electric bus implementation around the 
globe will also be conducted.
Stakeholder consultation: A stakeholder consultation 
event, in the form of an online workshop or one-on-one 
discussion sessions, will be conducted to verify the 
results of the desk study and benchmark analysis, 
identify further regulatory and implementation 
challenges met by the stakeholders, and identify options 
of policies to support the fleet electrification.
Document development: The resulting policy review and 
benchmarking study, as well as the identified 
implementation challenges and policy options from the 
stakeholder consultation event, will become the input for 
the policy recommendation document. A set of policy 
recommendations for policymakers will be presented in 
the final document.
This output is important because, although there is a 
presidential decree to kickstart a battery electric vehicle 
acceleration program, there are no clear plans nor policies targeted to public transport electrification. The 
missing policies at the national level hinder local 
governments from taking corresponding actions and the 
scarcity of financing options for bus operators to procure 
electric buses and install its infrastructure will remain 
unaddressed. Without any clear policy support and 
incentive, the deployment of electric buses will be 
hampered.

Project: Building Capacity and an Action Plan to Scale up Transjakarta E buses
Result_Title: Policy  recommendations  for national and  local  policymakers to  ensure the  sustainability of  EV in public  transport fleet  from business,  energy, and  operations  aspects
Description:
